title: Math 437 Example Project
text: Disclaimer: This project formatting is adapted from the Open Case Studies project. The purpose of the Open Case Studies project is to demonstrate the use of various data science methods, tools, and software in the context of messy, real-world data. A given case study does not cover all aspects of the research process, is not claiming to be the most appropriate way to analyze a given data set, and should not be used in the context of making policy decisions without external consultation from scientific experts.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Motivation and Context






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section describes what you are investigating in your project and why you are investigating it. You should provide enough contextual background and information that someone with a limited background can understand the broad outlines of the topic being investigated.








Dr. Wynne’s Note



There’s an invisible chunk that uses here::i_am to indicate the location of this file relative to the rest of the project website. The option echo: false makes the code invisible and the option message: false prevents the “here() starts at…” message from displaying.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Main Objective






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should introduce your main question or objective in the context you described above.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Packages Used In This Analysis






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section lists the packages used in the analysis. You should have a single chunk that loads the packages followed by a description of why you are using each package. Please use individual package names rather than tidyverse and tidymodels, to make it clear which specific packages are being used.
The Open Case Studies project uses a tabular form, which I replicate below.



library(here)
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(naniar)
library(rsample)
library(ggplot2)







Dr. Wynne’s Note



I included message: false and warning: false options in the chunk above so that package conflicts and similar issues aren’t shown when loading the packages.





Package
Use




here
to easily load and save data


readr
to import the CSV file data


dplyr
to massage and summarize data


naniar
to summarize and visualize missing data


rsample
to split data into training and test sets


ggplot2
to create nice-looking and informative graphs

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Data Description






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should describe the data that you are using, the source of the data (including a link), and how the data was originally collected. At the end of the section you should import the data.



Data Limitations






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This subsection should indicate limitations of your data. To quote from the project proposal prompt, consider:

Sources of bias in the data collection methods,
Mismatches between the variables in the dataset and the real-world characteristics they are intended to describe
Real-world differences that may make your model inappropriate for data collected from other times/places/etc.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Data Wrangling






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section contains any data wrangling you are doing. If you are creating training and test sets for predictive modeling, you should also include that code in an appropriate place in this section.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should include exploratory data analysis that is relevant to your objective.

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Modeling






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section must include, at minimum:

A description of how/why the technique(s) you chose work(s)
Code to fit the model(s), including any pre-processing you are doing on the training set
Code to calculate one or measures of model performance
Why you chose each measure of model performance, what those measures represent, and how they are calculated

title: Math 437 Example Project
text:
Insights






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should include one or more graphs, figures or tables that summarize your primary finding(s). You should also have a paragraph describing that finding in the text and summarizing how you arrived at it.



Limitations






Dr. Wynne’s Note




“All models are wrong, but some are useful.” - George Box
“All models are wrong, but some are wrong-er.” - Sam Behseta

This section should include further exploration of the limitations of your modeling approach. Some avenues of exploration include:

Who/what is being poorly predicted by your model? Why?
How might someone improve the data collection or analysis in the future?
Are the assumptions behind your analytical methods justified?
Are there ethical concerns about how the data was collected or how the results of the analysis could be used in the real world?





Reflection






Dr. Wynne’s Note



You will be turning in a reflection privately on Canvas. However, you may want to include excerpts from that reflection here if you are comfortable making them public; for example, addressing:

What did you learn about statistical learning from this project?
How did your work increase your understanding of the domain you applied it to?

title: Dr. Wynne’s Example Projects
text: I am Dwight Wynne, a lecturer in the Department of Mathematics at California State University, Fullerton (CSUF). I teach a variety of statistics and data science courses.

title: Dr. Wynne’s Example Projects
text:
Math 237: Foundations of Data Science
This course introduces students to basic techniques and thought processes in data science, including data collection, data wrangling, exploratory data analysis, frequentist and Bayesian statistical inference, and predictive modeling. This course is one of two courses that fulfills the Introduction to Data Science requirement for CSUF’s Data Science minor; as the other is upper division, this is likely the course that introductory data science courses at two-year institutions will articulate with.
Students end the semester by creating their first data science project. The Math 237 Example Project provides guidelines and an example for students completing this project.

title: Dr. Wynne’s Example Projects
text:
Math 437: Modern Data Analysis
This course was originally designed to introduce senior-level mathematics students to nonparametric and Bayesian inference, with clustering and neural networks introduced toward the end of the course. As data science and machine learning have become more popular, the emphasis has changed to supervised and unsupervised learning, with a focus on understanding the underlying mathematics.
Students end the semester by creating a project that applies supervised or unsupervised learning. The Math 437 Example Project provides guidelines and an example for students completing this project.

Packages Used In This Analysis






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section lists the packages used in the analysis. You should have a single chunk that loads the packages followed by a description you are using each package. The Open Case Studies project uses a tabular form, which I replicate below.



library(here)
library(readr)
library(dplyr)
library(sf)
library(jsonlite)







Dr. Wynne’s Note



I included message: false and warning: false options in the chunk above so that package conflicts and similar issues aren’t shown when loading the packages.





Package
Use




here

title: Math 237 Example Project
text:
Design and Data Collection






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This subsection should describe the data that you are using, the source of the data (including a link), and how the data was originally collected. At the end of the section you should import the data.

title: Math 237 Example Project
text:
Data Massaging






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should include most of your data wrangling. If you are creating training and test sets for predictive modeling, you should include that code in an appropriate place in this section.

title: Math 237 Example Project
text:
Exploratory Data Analysis






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should include exploratory data analysis that is relevant to your objective.

title: Math 237 Example Project
text:
Modeling






Dr. Wynne’s Note



If you are not building a model, you don’t need this section. Otherwise, this section should include your predictive or inferential modeling.

title: Math 237 Example Project
text:
Conclusion






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This section should include one or more graphs, figures or tables that summarize the primary finding with respect to your main objective. You should also have a paragraph describing that finding in the text and summarizing how you arrived at it.



Limitations






Dr. Wynne’s Note



This subsection should describe potential limitations of the conclusion and/or future work that someone might consider doing to expand on your analysis. Some limitations to discuss might include:

What are the real-world consequences of using your data or models? What are the consequences of an incorrect conclusion or prediction?
How appropriate was the data you used to answer your question? Consider aspects of validity (variables actually measure what you think they describe) and reliability (variable values would likely be similar if they were measured again).





Reflection






Dr. Wynne’s Note



You will be turning in a reflection privately on Canvas. However, you may want to include excerpts from that reflection here if you are comfortable making them public; for example, addressing:

What did you learn about data science from this project?
How did doing the data science increase your understanding of the domain you applied it to?
